name: Continuity Bonus Offer
description: Offer a high-value bonus (product, service, or content bundle) when customers sign up for continuity TODAY. The bonus typically has more value than the first continuity payment, incentivizing immediate action.

headline_patterns: Get [High-Value Bonus] FREE When You Join Today
Join Our [Membership] + Get [$X,XXX Value] As Our Gift
Sign Up Now & Get [All Past Content/Products] Included Free
offer_structure: Step 1: Present the continuity offer with clear monthly value
Step 2: Stack the bonus value (typically more than first payment)
Step 3: Create urgency - bonus only available if they join TODAY
Step 4: Explain how bonus complements ongoing subscription
bonus_examples: Physical Product: Get every [product] we've ever made for free ($800 value) when you sign up for monthly shipments at $59/mo
Digital Product: Get all 40 past newsletters ($15,880 value) when you become a member for $399/mo after 30-day trial
Service: Get Short-Term Accelerator ($1000 value) free when you join VIP membership at $100/mo
metrics: Bonus conversion lift: Target 20-40% increase in sign-up rate
LTV should exceed one-time sale by 3-4x over 12-20 months
Churn rate: Monitor if bonus hunters cancel after getting bonus
Make bonus related to core offer to attract right customers

name: Free Duration with Commitment
description: Give customers X free months/services if they commit to Y months. Four main approaches: (1) Upfront free time, (2) Free time at the end, (3) Spread discount over term, (4) After first payments. People think more about price than term.

headline_patterns: Get 3 Months FREE with Annual Commitment
Sign Up for 12 Months, Pay for Only 9
offer_structure: Step 1: Present standalone price (make it 1.33x-2.66x higher)
Step 2: Present continuity price with free duration
Step 3: Show total savings and how it spreads over commitment
Step 4: Emphasize the price advantage, de-emphasize the term
discount_application_methods: (1) UPFRONT: Free trial period, then contract starts (good for enforcing contracts like cell phones)
(2) AT THE END: Pay for X months, get Y months free at end (earn the discount)
(3) SPREAD OVER TIME: Discount applied every month across full term (keeps them engaged)
(4) AFTER FIRST PAYMENTS: Pay normally for 1-2 months, then get discount (covers advertising costs first)
metrics: Measure: % choosing commitment vs month-to-month
Track: Lifetime value of committed vs non-committed customers
Monitor: Early cancellation rate and reasons
Benchmark: Aim for 60-90% choosing commitment option

name: Waived Fee with Commitment
description: Waive your setup/onboarding/activation fee (typically 3-5x monthly rate) if customers commit to 12+ months. If they cancel early, they pay the fee. People avoid the fee by sticking around. Best for high-setup-cost businesses.

headline_patterns: Choose: $5000 Setup + $1000/mo Month-to-Month OR $0 Setup + $1000/mo × 12 Months
We'll Waive the $5000 Onboarding Fee If You Commit Long-Term
offer_structure: Step 1: Explain onboarding costs and why fee exists (setting up systems, training, resources)
Step 2: Present Option A: Pay fee + go month-to-month
Step 3: Present Option B: Waive fee entirely with 12+ month commitment
Step 4: Explain cancellation policy: Break commitment early = pay the fee
fee_sizing_guidelines: At minimum, commitment should be 12 months (ideally 12+)
Larger fee = more people choose commitment; Smaller fee = more upfront cash
Calculate: Does fee cover your actual customer acquisition/setup costs?
cancellation_policy: Make cancellation fee equal to the discount they received
Example: $5000 fee waived with 12mo commitment. If they cancel month 6, they pay $5000
Alternative: Prorated - they pay difference between commitment rate and month-to-month for months used
Bottom line: Leaving must cost more than staying
metrics: Track: % choosing committed vs month-to-month
Monitor: Cancellation rate and when cancellations occur
Calculate: Customer lifetime value - does fee waiver pay off?
Benchmark: 70-90% should choose commitment option
Key metric: If cost to quit > cost to stay, retention improves dramatically

name: Big Head, Long Tail (Downsell Upsell)
description: Sell a high upfront payment PLUS a small monthly fee. Get more cash upfront by selling shorter duration with added value for less. Example: Instead of $1000 one-time, offer $500 down + $50/mo. People focus on monthly price over term, locking in long-term revenue.

headline_patterns: Get More Value, Pay Less Per Month
Shorter Duration, Lower Monthly Price, More Value Added
offer_structure: Step 1: 'So you've enjoyed everything so far?' (acknowledge current satisfaction)
Step 2: 'Mind if I tell you about a way to save a little and get more?'
Step 3: 'Given you've enjoyed [current offer], we want you here long-term. Here's what we're gonna do...'
Step 4: 'If you're in this with us for the long term, we want to reward you with MORE stuff for LESS. Sound good?'
pricing_psychology: People think about MONTHLY CASH FLOW more than they think about DURATION
Power of commitments and contracts significantly increases LTV
Example: $100/10% churn = $1000 LTV. At $100/3% churn = $3000 LTV (3x improvement)
Downselling the upsell: Get cash upfront, sell shorter duration, add value, charge less monthly
value_stacking: Don't just lower price - ADD VALUE to justify continuity
Example: $5000 training program → $5000 down + $200/mo ongoing coaching
metrics: Track: Upfront revenue collected vs previous one-time model
Measure: Average customer stays X months (calculate total LTV)
Monitor: Churn rate - aim for <5% monthly
Benchmark: LTV should be 3-4x one-time sale over 12-20 months

name: Auto-Replenishment Subscription
description: Automatically ship consumable physical products on a recurring schedule. Customers never run out, you get predictable recurring revenue. Best for products with natural consumption cycles. Can offer discount vs one-time purchases.

headline_patterns: Never Run Out - Get [Product] Delivered Automatically
Monthly [Product] Box - Skip, Pause, or Cancel Anytime
offer_structure: Step 1: Identify the consumption cycle (how often they use/need product)
Step 2: Offer convenience (never run out, auto-delivery)
Step 3: Add incentive (discount vs one-time purchase, free shipping)
Step 4: Make it flexible (skip, pause, adjust frequency)
subscription_models: Replenishment: Same product delivered on schedule (dog food, supplements, razors)
Curation: Different products each delivery (subscription boxes, curated collections)
Access: Ongoing access to products + new releases (coffee club, book club)
value_propositions: Convenience: Never run out, automatic delivery
Exclusivity: Subscriber-only products or early access
Flexibility: Skip, pause, or modify subscription anytime
metrics: Churn rate: Aim for <10% monthly (this varies by industry)
Customer LTV: Calculate months retained × monthly value
Reactivation rate: % of cancelled subscribers who return
Net Revenue Retention: Track if subscribers upgrade/downgrade over time

name: Pure Monthly Subscription/Membership
description: Simple recurring monthly or annual subscription for access to content, software, community, or services. Clean, straightforward model. Best for SaaS, memberships, content libraries, and ongoing services with clear recurring value delivery.

offer_structure: Step 1: Clearly define what's included in membership
Step 2: Show ongoing value delivery (new content, features, support)
Step 3: Offer trial period or money-back guarantee
Step 4: Make sign-up easy with clear cancellation policy
pricing_strategies: Monthly vs Annual: Offer 15-20% discount for annual payment
Tiered Pricing: Basic/Pro/Premium levels with different feature sets
Billing Frequency: Bill every 4 weeks (not monthly) for 8.3% more annual revenue
Free Trial: 7-30 days to demonstrate value before charging
churn_reduction_tactics: Cancellation flow: Offer pause, downgrade, or discount before canceling
Exit interview: Understand why and offer to solve problem
Win-back campaigns: Re-engage cancelled members with special offers
Engagement monitoring: Reach out proactively when usage drops
metrics: Monthly Recurring Revenue (MRR): Total monthly subscription revenue
Churn Rate: Aim for <5% monthly for SaaS, <10% for content/coaching
LTGP (Lifetime Gross Profit) = Gross Margin × LTV
Net Revenue Retention: Are existing customers expanding or contracting?
Months to recover CAC: How long to break even on customer acquisition cost?
